children.value: sorting algorithm. It recursively divides the array into two halves until each subarray has only one element (which is trivially sorted). Then it
these sorted halves back together, comparing elements and building a larger sorted array step by step. This merging process continues until the entire array is reassembled in sorted order.
The algorithm has a consistent time complexity of

— it divides the array (log n times) and merges n elements at each level. Merge sort is stable and efficient but requires extra space proportional to the array size due to its temporary workspace array.
extra space on the list (recursive adds
= no recursion, often better constants and safer for huge inputs.
mirrors the textbook definition; very readable for students.
the “divide → conquer → combine” flow matches the mental model of merge sort.
left and right halves can be sorted concurrently if you go multi-threaded later.
merge step preserves order of equals.
stack frames. Usually fine, but it’s still extra memory and can matter on very tight stacks or unusual environments.
many small recursive calls; minor but measurable on some JVMs.

but the constant factor isn’t free.
avoids stack growth entirely; safer for
one linear pass per run size; practical throughput often edges out recursive on linked lists.
all in loops; easy to bound and instrument.

more places to make off-by-one / null-next mistakes; trickier to get right first time.
bottom-up run doubling is less obvious than “split in half”.
up front or advances pointers carefully; again, more book-keeping.
